title: Reminiscences of childhood at Inverkeithing;
author: Simson, James
snippet: The little village called Hillend, near the upper end of Letham Hill (which is said to be now entirely occupied  by Irish), is associated in my memory mainly with its teacher, of the name of Scotland, having been thrashed by his scholars ; and by the second boy of the family asking "if it was Scotland o' Hillend that was told to draw the sword," on hearing our maid singing, " Draw the sword, Scotland." It was also the headquarters  of a rather peculiar man who " whipped the cat " around the country,  that is, tailored from house to house.

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: As soon as he could escape from the dinner-table, Robert repaired to the stables, where he found his horse ready saddledfor him, according to his instructions. Mounting, he roderapidly out by the Comiston Eoad, Lothian Burn, and Hillend,to New Pentland. Need we ask why ? A concert was to beheld that night in aid of some school-children's treat.
